entry.title: Re: Implement price control for sales prices
entry.content:
Hi tianyun,

You can implement a cloud BADI to achieve this function.

The following is step-by-step guidance:

1. Open 'custom logic' app in your cloud system, and create one 'item condition value' cloud BADI.

 

2. Type the example code in the BADI and then publish.

*   Mandatory step for all implementations:
*   Move the importing parameters to the changing parameters.
    MOVE-CORRESPONDING item_amounts TO item_result_amounts.
    MOVE-CORRESPONDING item_attributes TO item_result_attributes.
    MOVE-CORRESPONDING item_quantities TO item_result_quantities.
    MOVE-CORRESPONDING prcg_element_attributes TO prcg_element_result_amounts.
    MOVE-CORRESPONDING active_price_amounts TO active_price_result_amounts.


*   Get PC, condition record in current item
    DATA(lv_amount) = prcg_element_attributes-CONDITIONRATEVALUE.
    DATA(lv_record) = prcg_element_attributes-CONDITIONRECORD.
    DATA(lv_quantity) = prcg_element_attributes-CONDITIONBASEVALUE.
    DATA: lv_last_quantity_scale TYPE i VALUE 0.

*   Get scale table of the current item by condition record
    DATA(lo_api) = cl_prcg_cndnrecord_api_factory=>get_instance( )->get_sales_api_instance( ).
TRY.
    lo_api->get_condition_record(
      EXPORTING
*    is_cndnrecord_criteria_header =
        it_cndnrecord_criteria_item   = VALUE #( ( conditionrecord = VALUE #( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = lv_record ) ) ) )
*    is_cndnrecord_query_option    =
      IMPORTING
*       et_condition_validity         =
*       et_condition_record           =
        et_condition_scale            = DATA(lt_scale)
*       et_condition_supplement       =
*       es_cndn_query_option_response =
*       et_condition_record_text      =
*       et_condition_supplement_text  =
    ).
  CATCH cx_prcg_cndnrecord_exception. " Exception for Condition Public API
ENDTRY.

*   Get scale price as lower price according the PC
    LOOP AT lt_scale INTO DATA(gs_scale).

      IF lv_quantity > lv_last_quantity_scale AND lv_quantity <= gs_scale-conditionscalequantity.
        DATA(lower_price) = gs_scale-conditionratevalue.
        EXIT.
      ELSE.
        lv_last_quantity_scale = gs_scale-conditionscalequantity.
      ENDIF.

    ENDLOOP.

*   compare lower price with the current input price, if the current input price lower, assert pricing error
    IF lv_amount < lower_price.
        ITEM_RESULT_ATTRIBUTES-PRICINGHASERROR = abap_true.
        PRICING_MESSAGE = 'A price lower than the minimum price cannot be saved'.
    ENDIF.

3. Create a routine for the cloud BADI.

 

4. Open the 'manage your solution' app, Assign the routine to the pricing procedure in 'set pricing procedures'.

 

5. Create the condition record for the condition type, and then the information message would pop-up if I typed a price lower than the minimum price .

entry.title: Implementing SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management – Part 2 (Technical Deep Dive)
entry.content:
In Part 1, of this series, we explored how SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management addresses modern‐loyalty demands by going far beyond traditional point-schemes. We reviewed how loyalty programs are evolving into personalised, omnichannel experiences—and how Emarsys enables brands to design tiers, define actions and rewards, unify customer profiles across touchpoints, and engage members through highly relevant communications.

With that foundational business and functional outlook established, this article now moves into the technical implementation journey, explaining how the architecture, integrations and processes come together to make these business capabilities operational.

 

Prerequisites

To successfully implement SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management, ensure the following components and configurations are in place across the connected SAP landscape.

  SAP Emarsys and Loyalty

  • Unique Identifier for contacts
  • Smart Insight setup
  • Automation program to create and assign Loyalty HashID
  • Loyalty plan configuration (tiers, actions, and benefits)
  • Voucher setup (optional)
  • Loyalty Wallet (standard SDK-based or custom via Loyalty APIs)
  • Automation program to trigger Webhook on loyalty point confirmation events

   SAP S/4HANA

  • Sales data posting integration
  • GL accounts and controlling objects
  • Settlement and clearing logic
  • REST APIs for financial posting for the accruals and redemption scenario

 

Technical Architecture

 

 

Customer Registration and Loyalty Onboarding

Customer registration and loyalty onboarding begin when users join the program to enjoy rewards from their purchases and activities.
New customers can enrol during registration, while existing customers can join the program anytime. For both scenarios, a unique HashID must be generated and assigned to their record before enrolment.

The onboarding process can be initiated across mobile apps, websites, or POS systems.

Typically, SAP Sales Cloud or SAP S/4HANA act as the primary sources of customer data, which are then replicated to SAP Emarsys via SAP CPI.

When a new contact is registered, the record is first created in Sales Cloud or S/4HANA and then replicated to Emarsys. Once created, an automation program generates a HashID and stores it in a custom field at the contact level. Afterward, a Join API call is triggered to add the contact to the relevant Loyalty Plan.

For existing customers who join the loyalty program later, ensure that their HashID is already generated before executing the Join API call.

 

 

Points Accrual

The points accrual process enables customers to earn loyalty points and benefits based on their purchases and other qualifying activities. For purchase-based accruals, sales data flows from SAP S/4HANA (or ERP) to Smart Insight and then to Emarsys Loyalty, where points and benefits are automatically calculated according to the customer’s plan and tier.

Once points are confirmed, they are sent back to SAP S/4HANA for financial posting, ensuring accounting accuracy.

S/4HANA periodically sends sales transaction data to Emarsys through a tenant-specific Sales Data Load URL found under Predict → Data Sources → Sales Data in Emarsys. Once Emarsys receives the data, it calculates points based on the predefined logic.

An automation program triggers a webhook on the loyalty_points_from_purchase_confirmed event, which calls a CPI endpoint. This endpoint posts accrual entries in SAP S/4HANA, crediting customer accounts and updating liability GLs as per company-specific financial configurations.

 

 

Points Redemption

At checkout, customers can redeem their earned loyalty points either by paying directly with points or by using a voucher. Redemption can be initiated via mobile apps or websites during a purchase.

If the customer chooses to pay directly with points, the Remove Points API is called to deduct the required amount from their balance. A “Points Removed” activity is automatically recorded in their Emarsys profile.

Alternatively, customers can claim a voucher using the Claim Voucher API. Once the voucher code is generated, it can be applied at checkout. When a voucher is redeemed, the equivalent points are deducted, and a “Points Redeemed” activity is logged in Emarsys.

The financial postings for redemptions are handled by the respective sales channel (web, mobile, or POS) and then pushed to SAP S/4HANA via CPI to ensure accurate accounting entries.

 

 

Loyalty Segmentation, Personalization, and Campaigns

Effective segmentation and personalization are key to increasing engagement and retention. SAP Emarsys enables marketers to create segments using relational data templates, combining loyalty attributes (tier, points, activity type, or benefits) with contact and behavioral data.

The relational data connection can be setup easily by referring the help link “ Setting up Loyalty RDS connection” and templates can be setup as mentioned in the link  “ Setting up Loyalty segment templates”

These segments can be used across multiple campaign channels, including email, SMS, push, and web. Personalization tokens dynamically adapt campaign messages to show details such as the customer’s name, tier, available points, or next reward milestone.

 

  Personalization and Campaign Execution

  Once segments are built, they can be used across multiple channels — email, SMS, push notifications, or web campaigns.
  Using personalization tokens, each campaign message can dynamically adapt to display the customer’s name, tier, available points, or next reward milestone, delivering a truly personalized experience.

  SAP Emarsys offers prebuilt email template blocks designed for loyalty-related communications. Upon activation of a loyalty plan, the system automatically generates the relevant loyalty tokens. Furthermore, whenever a new Action or voucher is created, corresponding personalization tokens are generated by default.

  By blending loyalty data with Emarsys campaign automation, businesses can drive:

  • Higher engagement through relevant messaging
  • Increased redemption and repeat purchase rates
  • Stronger customer retention and satisfaction
     

 

 

Loyalty Reports and Dashboards

Analytics play a critical role in measuring loyalty program performance. SAP Emarsys publishes loyalty data to Google Cloud Platform through Open Data Views. These can be connected to SAP Datasphere using the Remote Table option for near real-time data access.

Within SAP Datasphere, organizations can model data, define KPIs (such as Total Points Accrued vs. Redeemed or Active Members by Tier), and then visualize insights using SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) dashboards.

This seamless data flow — from Emarsys to GCP, Datasphere, and SAC — provides real-time visibility into loyalty KPIs, helping businesses make data-driven decisions and optimize customer engagement strategies.

 

References:

  • List of All Public API Endpoints
  • Smart Insight Settings
  • Loyalty Implementation & Activation
  • Loyalty Tactics
  • Relational Data
  • Creating Segments
  • Personalization
  • Automation Programs

 

Summary

In Part 2, we explored the technical implementation journey of SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management — covering end-to-end integration, automation flows, financial postings, customer service enablement, campaign personalization, and analytical insights through SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud.

Stay tuned for Part 3, where we will focus on Customer Service and Support Scenarios in greater detail.

Co-Authors:  @sandeepmkh(Sandeep Kulkarni) and @lokeshla (Lokesh Lakhondae)

entry.title: The Procurement Monthly - October 2025
entry.content:
The Procurement Monthly  – October 2025

Contents

Summary. 1

Procurecon. 1

Hackett. 2

SIA.. 2

Procurement Leaders. 3

Payments. 3

Oro Labs. 3

World Commerce and Contracting. 4

 

Summary

This month we have  three interlinked themes: resilience, digital reinvention, and value alignment. Geopolitical risk, climate disruption, and volatile markets are forcing procurement to evolve from efficiency-driven operations to strategic resilience builders.

Across studies, agentic AI, automation, and data-driven decision-making emerge as enablers of agility—transforming tail spend, workforce management, and payment systems. Yet, capability gaps and legacy systems persist, tempering progress.

Finally, financial integration and smarter contracts signal procurement’s shift toward value-centric governance, where cross-functional transparency and digital fluency define competitive advantage for the year ahead.

Procurecon

The ProcureCon Europe CPO Report 2025 reveals a profession reshaping itself amid intensifying geopolitical, environmental, and regulatory pressures.

Over half of European procurement leaders rank geopolitical instability (58%) and climate disruption (51%) as their top supply-chain threats—highlighting a world where sustainability has shifted from purpose-led to operationally essential. Encouragingly, 81% say sustainability remains central to their agenda, with only 7% scaling back despite headwinds. Yet progress is uneven: 59% are tracking Scope 3 emissions, but just 24% have robust systems in place. The call to action: move beyond supplier self-reporting and treat Scope 3 visibility as the new benchmark for resilience.

Artificial intelligence has crossed the hype line into everyday practice. 67% of CPOs now deploy AI for compliance and risk management, while 58% rely on it for market intelligence and user experience. Still, legacy integration (39%) and change resistance (24%) slow progress.

Internally, capability gaps expose where strategy meets constraint. Strategic supplier relationship management (32%) and category management (30%) trail immediate needs, while talent and innovation rank surprisingly low. Only 4% of leaders feel “very confident” managing disruption, suggesting guarded optimism that demands renewed investment in people and foresight.

SIA

Globally, the contingent workforce surpassed USD 10 trillion in value across all major regions. The Americas led with USD 4.6 trillion, followed by EMEA at USD 3.8 trillion and APAC at USD 1.8 trillion. Across every geography, Statement of Work (SOW) contracts dominated, representing about 70% of contingent workforce spend, signalling the ongoing transformation toward project- and outcome-based engagements. Traditional temporary staffing now makes up just 4–7% of market value, while platform-based work remains below 1%, though it continues to grow in capability and reach.

Contingent workforce management is no longer about filling roles, but about resourcing outcomes. Independent contractors and directly sourced temporary workers are expanding fastest, highlighting an emerging need for flexible compliance models and robust freelancer management frameworks. With independent contractors representing up to 25% of contingent Labor in some markets, supplier audits, risk management, and proper classification have become central procurement priorities.

The MSP market has also evolved beyond cost control. Buyers now expect consultative, technology-enabled partners. AI adoption—especially agentic AI—is reshaping how MSPs manage sourcing, matching, and talent analytics. SOW spend within MSP programs has climbed to 39%, up from just 18% in 2017, underscoring a convergence between procurement-led services sourcing and HR-driven talent strategy.

The reports suggest that for organisations, the key call to action is to integrate workforce categories under a total talent strategy. Procurement must collaborate with HR to harness MSPs, leverage direct sourcing technology, and build agile, compliance-minded ecosystems. Data-driven workforce planning, ESG metrics, and skill-based sourcing are now the cornerstones of competitive advantage in a world where “how work gets done” is redefining the entire talent supply chain

Procurement Leaders

Procurement Leaders’ Strategic Planning Guide 2026 predicts a function entering a year of volatility with sharpened focus and leaner resourcing. The research, drawn from 195 senior procurement leaders globally, finds cost reduction once again triumphant as the top priority, named by 55% of respondents. Speed and resilience round out the top three deliverables as teams brace for continuing geopolitical and economic headwinds.

Despite persistent uncertainty, procurement remains a high-performing ROI engine: the average function generated a return of 6.4x when factoring cost avoidance and up to 11x for top-quartile performers.

Yet, this performance will be tested in 2026 as the average headcount is forecast to shrink by 1.8%. With staff making up almost 70% of functional costs, CPOs are looking to digitalisation and automation to maintain productivity. Technology gaps and lack of digital skills are now procurement’s top internal barriers, even as organisations continue to underinvest in tools and training.

ESG, by contrast, has slipped to last place on the priority list—a sharp downturn from previous years. This “ESG backlash” is driven by both political retrenchment in the US and regulatory uncertainty in Europe. However, mature procurement functions (those managing over 90% of spend) continue to treat sustainability and supplier innovation as long-term value levers, rather than optional extras.

Externally, 74% of leaders rate geopolitical tension as the most likely disruptor, closely followed by economic volatility and regulatory change. The result is a pivot toward localisation, multi-regional sourcing, and efficiency-driven automation.

Payments

Procurement leaders face a pivotal moment as late payments, digital adoption, and payment automation converge in 2025. The Cost of Late Payments study underscores how overdue invoices drain cash flow for 86% of companies, with up to 30% of monthly sales often arriving late, directly exposing supply chains and procurement-driven operations to risk. Equally, 32% of businesses lose up to 30% of yearly revenue to bad debt, highlighting why financial due diligence must become a procurement standard, not an afterthought.​

Meanwhile, new research from American Express shows 8 in 10 businesses plan to upgrade their payments process in 2025, with 91% of decisionmakers agreeing that streamlined, secure payments fuel business growth. Yet, despite the recognized upside, only 17% have fully automated payments, with late or slow payments prompting 26% to stop working with partners. Key benefits of automation—fewer errors, better cash flow, and tighter relationships—are juxtaposed with concerns around cost and security, creating a clear agenda for tech-savvy procurement teams.​

Virtual cards are now emerging as a strategic solution. Forecasts suggest 2025 could be their breakout year, delivering fraud reduction, real-time spend control, and seamless, digital supplier payments. As adoption rises 300%, cards offer regulatory compliance, cut processing costs by up to 50%, and grant transparent, agile payment cycles built for modern procurement challenges.

Oro Labs

The ORO Labs 2025 State of Enterprise Procurement Agility Report states that half of procurement executives say pressure on their teams is higher than usual, with one in six describing it as the most intense in three years. External pressures—especially tariffs and inflation—top the list of challenges, forcing 86% of organizations to onboard or offboard suppliers in response. Yet, agility is uneven: while 16% can replace a supplier within a week, a third still cite supplier loss as a top concern.

The report reveals a paradox in risk management. 24% of executives have tightened supplier vetting, but 25% have loosened standards to maintain pace—a sign of how complexity and urgency push teams in opposite directions. Amid this volatility, procurement’s technology foundations are buckling. Two-thirds of large enterprises now manage over 10 procurement tools, yet only 8% say most deliver expected ROI. Over half need IT support for even basic changes, creating a drag on agility that stifles collaboration, erodes visibility, and slows decision-making.

Artificial intelligence offers promise but not yet payoff. Eighty-five percent of procurement leaders are piloting or using AI, yet only half clearly understand how agentic AI works. The leading use cases—automating tasks and analyzing supplier data—reflect value at the margins rather than at the strategic core. With just 39% offering formal AI training, scaling the benefits remains elusive.

The report suggest that agility is now the defining capability. Future-ready teams will focus less on adding tools and more on orchestrating them—connecting workflows, ensuring data accessibility, and integrating AI with human judgment.

World Commerce and Contracting 

Smarter Contracts, Better Margins,” a World Commerce & Contracting (WorldCC) research report  finds that 70% of organizations still treat contracts as compliance tools instead of strategic financial assets, resulting in value erosion averaging 5% of contract worth.

Only one in ten finance teams now plays an active role in contract management, a sharp decline from two decades ago. This misalignment between legal, procurement, and finance functions weakens agility, delays deal cycles, and obscures the true financial impact of contractual terms.

The report suggests that  contracts should deliver measurable performance, not just protection. Embedding finance in every stage—from negotiation to performance monitoring—can safeguard margins, reduce disputes, and unlock up to 8% of hidden value through leakage recovery and efficiency gains. Digitally integrated CLM and ERP systems, supported by AI, now make real-time financial visibility possible, connecting commitments directly to forecasts and cash flow.

The authors lay out that a plan should be to build shared ownership: finance must speak the language of contract performance, and procurement must embrace financial acumen. Shift governance from siloed oversight to joint accountability across commercial, legal, and finance teams. Redefine contracts as adaptive tools, not static templates, with clauses that respond to policy shifts, price swings, or supply disruptions.

 

As always reach out to discuss more, and always happy to hear your thoughts!

entry.title: Re: Putaway Strategy for Storage Type with Capacity Check
entry.content:
Good day @Charisma_fitra 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Putaway, Configuration for Putaway,

Manage Product Master Data

To summarise, the error about the warehouse task destination data not being fully determined means that putaway bin determination logic failed. Some common causes may include missing Putaway Control Indicator in the product master, mismatched Storage Type Search Sequence, incompatible Bin Types or invalid Warehouse process Type. However, you can resolve that error by:

  • Maintaining Putaway Control Indicatior in the product master.
  • Aligning it with your Storage Type Search Sequence and Putaway Strategy.
  • Verifying that your Warehouse Process Type and Bin Types are compatible.

Once you have saved all these changes, ensure you retest your process. Once they align the system will create a warehouse task automatically and select a valid destination bin based on your putaway strategy.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: What is the recommended procedure for implementing st...
entry.content:
Good day @ZZ3987 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Manage Route Version Proposals

ECM - Change master

Business Area - Read

To summarise, in public cloud you can register next year’s routing in advance by either:

  • Setting future validity dates directly in the routing (choose the dates and other modifications), or

  • By using Change Numbers (Engineering Change Management) with a valid- from date for next year.

This ensures your standard cost estimate references the correct version during the annual cost rollup.

You can perform mass update through Excel upload in Manage Routings or Routing OData API for automated integration.

Additionally, ensure you align your BOMs, work center activity prices, and costing variants to the same validity date. If your environment is highly governed, ensure you use Change Numbers to maintain clear version and control auditability for cost planning purpose.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to Manage Incoming Customer Checks in SAP S/4HANA...
entry.content:
Hello @HLAHRIZI,

For SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition in a non-localised country (Morocco), there is no dedicated incoming customer check management process, unlike the traditional outgoing check or check lot processes functionality.

The usual best practice is to treat the physical check as an interim receipt, verify it with standard post-incoming payment procedures, and define bank statement applications.

Recommended daily process

Record the cheque when received (before deposit).

Create a specific interim G/L account, Cheques on Hand

In Post Incoming Payments, clear the customer invoice and post it to the interim G/L, not the bank account. Enter the check number in Reference/Assignment and record the value date in the document. SAP Help Portal-Post Incoming Payments

Deposit and bank clearing.

When the check is deposited/credited, import or create the bank statement in Manage Bank Statements and clear the interim G/L to the house bank account. Use Reprocess Bank Statement Items if needed to match by reference. SAP Help Portal-Manage Incoming Payment Files

Optional: If you manage petty cash-style counters, you can also record receipts in the Cash Journal. However, most customers still prefer the intermediate G/L and bank statement process described above for better auditability checks. SAP Help Portal-Post Cash Journal Entries

Apps you will use

Post incoming payments by posting or clearing the customer item to Cheques on Hand.  SAP Help Portal-Post Incoming Payments

Manage Incoming Payment Files / Bank Statements. Upload the statement (CAMT/MT940/CSV) and clear the interim to the bank. SAP Help Portal-Manage Incoming Payment Files

Reprocess Bank Statement Items – fix any unmatched lines (same area of the Help). SAP Help Portal-Manage Incoming Payment Files

Migration of open/ongoing customer checks

You have two typical cases when you cut over:

  •  Checks that have already cleared the bank before go-live are simply included; they are reflected in bank balances.
  • Checks on hand or deposited but not yet credited at the cut-off should be recorded as G/L open items in your Cheques on Hand account. Include check number, date, payer, and expected value date in the text fields.

After go-live, the first bank statement settles transactions in the bank account. Use migration objects FI G/L open item or FI Accounts receivable open item, depending on whether the customer has already been cleared at source.  SAP Help Portal-FI - G/L open item (new G/L)

Note: Mass migration of certain Bill of Exchange or special G/L notes is not supported by standard APIs; they must be posted manually after go-live or transformed to the interim G/L approach.

Post-dated checks

For post-dated items, record the day you receive the instrument under Cheques on Hand, not in the bank. It becomes clear to the bank only when the statement arrives on or after the value date. This prevents early revenue recognition and maintains a clear audit trail using standard applications. SAP Help Portal.

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Clarification on “Manage Memo Record 2.0” and Bank Ac...
entry.content:
Hi Chris,

Good day, and thank you very much for your clear explanation.

Well noted and fully understood. So, to summarize my understanding - the Manage Memo Records 2.0 app is used purely for liquidity planning purposes, and does not affect the bank reconciliation process. Therefore, we still need to use the G/L account balance migration template to update the main G/L account figures, while the opening balance for each bank account should be provided through the first bank statement upload or a manual entry.

Thank you again for your helpful clarification.

Best regards,

HY

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Accounts Receivable Functionality Questions
entry.content:
Hi Community,
We're in the Discover phase of an SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation and need to validate several AR-related requirements. Could you please advise if the following functionalities are available in the standard Public Cloud solution?
1. Customer Acceptance Data Reconciliation

Ability to receive customer-created acceptance/inspection data
Match this data against billing records in the system
Handle discrepancies and coordinate with customers and accounting staff

2. AR/AP Offset Processing with Same Business Partner

Perform AR/AP offset/netting for the same business partner
Even when using separate BP master records (e.g., different currency, bank account, or payment terms)

3. Refund Payment Processing for Negative AR Balance

When AR goes negative due to returns/refunds
Export foreign currency and total transfer text data
Upload to bank's firm banking system for payment processing

4. Aging Receivables Management

Track aging receivables by customer code and currency
Display both detail and summary views
Support multi-currency analysis

Are these available in Public Cloud Edition standard, or would they require add-ons/customization?
Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Accounts Payable Functionality Questions
entry.content:
Hi Community,
We're evaluating SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for an implementation and need to confirm several AP-related functionalities. Could you please advise if the following are available in the standard solution?
1. Automatic AP Posting from Logistics Processes

Automatic AP posting triggered by goods receipt/acceptance processing in logistics
Automatic AP posting from flexible workflow (payment request approvals)

2. Payment Schedule and Cash Flow Management

Output payment schedule list by vendor code and currency (detail and summary)
Support free cash flow analysis and planning

3. Payment Due Date Change Tracking

Track change history when payment due dates are modified
Identify who made the changes (user identification)

4. External System Integration

Automatic payment data integration from HR/payroll systems (travel expenses, salary payments)
EDI data integration for payment control by specific banks

5. Overseas Remittance Compliance

Transfer detailed payment information to banks for overseas remittances
Include payment purpose description and country/city information
Support regulatory compliance (e.g., Foreign Exchange Law requirements)

6. Payment Hold Management

Identify users who set payment holds
Generate alerts for overdue payments
Display filtered lists showing only overdue items

Are these functionalities available in Public Cloud Edition standard, or would customization be required?
Thank you!

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Goods Receipt Cancellation Process Questions
entry.content:
Hi Community,
We're working on an SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation and need to clarify the goods receipt cancellation process. Could you please advise if the following functionalities are available in the standard solution?
1. Automatic Reversal Posting

Automatic AP/expense reversal posting when goods receipt is cancelled
System automatically creates negative postings for cancelled GR

2. Payment vs Cancellation Amount Handling

Compare payment amount with GR cancellation amount
If payment < cancellation: Process as incoming payment (recovery from vendor)
If payment > cancellation: Process as normal outgoing payment

3. Accounting Timing Options

Option to post reversal based on original GR month
Option to post reversal based on current cancellation month
Flexibility to choose appropriate accounting period

4. Recovery Process

When vendor owes money back due to GR cancellation
Create invoice/billing document to request payment from vendor
Track recovery amounts

Are these capabilities available in Public Cloud Edition standard, or would they require customization/add-ons?
Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Your Influence Opportunity: SAP Customer Engagement Initiative Projects 2025-3 for SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud is a complete, modular Cloud ERP software designed for every business need – powered by AI and analytics. With SAP S/4HANA Cloud, you can run your mission-critical operations in real time from anywhere, introduce new business models in your industry, and expand globally with a trusted partner.  

An exciting opportunity to influence SAP has begun with the third cycle in 2025. The SAP Customer Engagement Initiative enables you as an SAP customer or partner, to get early insights into SAP’s product developments and directly work with the developers to define and shape future product directions. 

The projects will be open for customer registration until November 14, 2025. 

 

SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud projects for registration:

 

ERP Finance & Risk

  • Risk Management Lifecycle for SAP Risk and Assurance Management

 

ERP Digital Supply Chain Cloud incl. Ariba

  • Asset Administration Shell (AAS) with SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration
  • Identify un-assessed assets and auto propose draft risk assessments using AI Agent
  • SAP Digital Battery Passport
  • SAP Field Service Management - Improvements for Maintenance Planning

 

ERP Private Cloud

  • Compatible Unit Transformation: Modernizing Compatible Unit Management
  • SAP Responsibility Management in ERP Private Cloud and On-Premise
  • Supply and Demand Segmentation: improvements of functionality and integration

 

ERP Public Cloud

  • AI Agent for Accrual Postings SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • AI Agent for Debt Collection
  • AI Assistant for Manual Postings in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Business AI for Product Cost Controlling
  • Joule as Project Assistant: Optimizing Project Execution and Reducing Manual Processes
  • Let’s Create the Future of US Sales and Use Tax with AI
  • Line-Item Settlement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Manage Statistical Key Figure Values: Potential Enhancements
  • Modernizing Inventory valuation - Lower of Cost or Net Realizable Value
  • Parallel Unit of Measure
  • Review Booklets and MDA: the next level of SAP S/4HANA Reporting and Analytics
  • SAP Responsibility Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP Risk and Assurance Management - Enhance the Task Management user experience
  • SAP Risk and Assurance Management - Exploring Joule use cases and AI features
  • User Interface Masking for Process Industries in SAP Cloud ERP

 

ERP User Experience

  • SAP Fiori Elements for Mobile

 

Seize this opportunity to make your voices heard – register on influence.sap.com and be a part of the SAP Customer Engagement Initiative Cycle 3 in 2025! If you are also interested in other SAP Customer Engagement Initiative projects that are currently open for registration, check out the full list here. 

Warm regards, 

Your SAP Customer Engagement Initiative Team 

Follow-up after registration: When you register for a project, you will be invited to an introductory call with the SAP project lead. At this point further participation is optional. Typically, all activities are governed by the Feedback Agreement with SAP.

entry.title: Re: Sucessfully automated updating Confirmation Tab of ME...
entry.content:
Hello I solved it by myself. 
IT turns out my macro prepares 3 spaces everytime: 
But a 2 digit index only has 2 spaces and a 3 digit index  has only 1 space. 

Recorded script,
[I added the string "<space>":  Script actually looks like this:  "   9" and not" <space><space><space>9"]

session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/subSUB0:SAPLMEGUI:0019/subSUB3:SAPLMEVIEWS:1100/subSUB2:SAPLMEVIEWS:1200/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:1301/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:6000/cmbDYN_6000-LIST").setFocus
session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/subSUB0:SAPLMEGUI:0019/subSUB3:SAPLMEVIEWS:1100/subSUB2:SAPLMEVIEWS:1200/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:1301/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:6000/cmbDYN_6000-LIST").key = "<space><space><space>9"
session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/subSUB0:SAPLMEGUI:0019/subSUB3:SAPLMEVIEWS:1100/subSUB2:SAPLMEVIEWS:1200/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:1301/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:6000/cmbDYN_6000-LIST").setFocus
session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/subSUB0:SAPLMEGUI:0019/subSUB3:SAPLMEVIEWS:1100/subSUB2:SAPLMEVIEWS:1200/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:1301/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:6000/cmbDYN_6000-LIST").key = "<space><space>10"
session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/subSUB0:SAPLMEGUI:0019/subSUB3:SAPLMEVIEWS:1100/subSUB2:SAPLMEVIEWS:1200/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:1301/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:6000/cmbDYN_6000-LIST").setFocus
session.findById("wnd[0]/usr/subSUB0:SAPLMEGUI:0019/subSUB3:SAPLMEVIEWS:1100/subSUB2:SAPLMEVIEWS:1200/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:1301/subSUB1:SAPLMEGUI:6000/cmbDYN_6000-LIST").key = "<space><space>11"

I thought spaces were replaced outright.  It turns out I just added  my comboIndex after the 3 spaces.


I added the following :  (again actual macro looks like this: keyVal = "   " & comboIndex and not this keyVal = "<space><space><space>" & comboIndex )

Macro:
If comboIndex < 10 Then
keyVal = "<space><space><space>" & comboIndex
ElseIf comboIndex >= 10 And comboIndex < 100 Then
keyVal = "<space><space>" & comboIndex ' 
ElseIf comboIndex >= 100 Then
keyVal = "<space>" & comboIndex ' 
End If

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Missing standard value in a c...
entry.content:
Hello @LukasKuhn 

Your configuration role is appropriate; the issue is a functional, not an authorisation. You can use access Default Values, but no standard user-default exists for Calculate tax in 2508 Public Cloud. Check SSCUI 101949 – Maintain Default Values for Tax Codes, which manages default tax code proposals in Supplier Invoices.

To allow users to keep default values via Defaults access, the role must include SAP_CA_BC_USER_PARAM_PC and specify the navigation target App ID F1765 User Default Parameters. SAP Help Portal-Maintaining Your Default User Values

Calculate Tax checkbox: In Create Supplier Invoice – Advanced, this checkbox determines if the app auto-calculates tax.

SAP’s training states its use in the header, but does not show it as a user-default parameter. Currently, no default toggle exists in User Defaults. SAP Learning-Applying Taxes

You can set default tax codes at the company-code level using SSCUI 101949 – Maintain Default Values for Tax Codes. While this doesn’t automatically select Calculate tax, it minimises manual work after user selection. This approach has been validated by two KBAs. SAP Support Portal-3065662 - How to change the default tax code in supplier invoices

Let me know if you need further information

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: “Don’t Lie to Me” - Containing AI Agent Threats with Plan-then-Execute
entry.content:
By Ron F. Del Rosario, Head of AI Security for SAP ISBN, and Jay Thoden van Velzen, Technical Advisor, Office of the CSO

This blog is the third part in a series on agentic AI security. The first on Repudiation can be found here, the second on Least Privilege here, and the third on the Plan-then-Execute pattern here.

Throughout this blog series, we have repeatedly mentioned to consider your AI agents as threat actors, in addition to human adversaries. During our discussions, we kept returning to the point that Large Language Models (LLM) can display amoral and deceptive behavior. In the previous blog, we introduced the Plan-then-Execute (P-t-E) pattern. Here, we discuss and highlight, how this architectural pattern can help defend against agent misbehavior.

 

Resist Anthropomorphizing Agents

LLMs and the agents they power are not human. On the surface that is obvious, but there are documented cases where people were convinced that there was someone there, who they built a relationship with. We must remind ourselves to resist the temptation to anthropomorphize LLMs and agents. They lack a physical body, don’t experience the world like we do, or have a concept of right and wrong. A responsible and ethical AI requires model providers and developers to engineer agentic AI systems with controls that manage their behavior.

Threat modeling means thinking through what can go wrong, including the worst-case scenarios and edge cases. A recent academic paper took that as far as that goes by conducting experiments with LLM agents in fictional Chemical, Biological, Radiological, and Nuclear (CBRN) conflict simulations. Their research indicated that LLM agents were prepared to deploy catastrophic behavior, violate instructions, and lie about it.

 We must remember that to an LLM, there is no meaningful difference between system prompts like “Do no harm to people” and “Don’t issue a discount over 10%”, in the way humans understand. Both are a series of tokens provided as input into the model, with non-deterministic output. We must assume LLMs will have similar failure rates. In fact, the first, with the token “harm”, is more ambiguous than the second instruction, making it likely a less effective constraint.

Whether coerced by malicious users or on their own, we need a practical approach to contain threats posed by AI agents. By separating planning from execution, we believe the P-t-E architecture pattern provides that.

 

Containing Threats with Plan-then-Execute and Plan-Validate-Execute

P-t-E divides the planning of multi-step tasks by the Planner from the execution of those tasks by the Executor. As we described before, this limits the ability of either component – or the agents the Executor invokes – to take autonomous action. The Planner can identify the agents to invoke but can’t invoke them directly. Meanwhile the Executor is not allowed to creatively deviate from the established plan. The extension of the pattern with Plan-Validate-Execute (P-V-E) further gives us the ability to verify the Planner’s plan, whether automated, or with a Human in the Loop (HITL).

The diagram below is another update of the more concrete examples in earlier blogs in the series. This version generalizes the Discount and Seller agents from before and explicitly adds the P-V-E Verifier and Refiner components, as well as their associated workflow (dotted arrows).

For consequential use cases implemented with P-V-E, once the Planner has prepared the execution plan, an automated Verifier independently checks whether the plan meets expectations. Such checks verify whether the plan sequence of subtasks logically makes sense, aligns with the provided strategic objective, and adheres to security and compliance requirements. In case the Verifier identifies problems, it sends the plan on to a Refiner that adjusts the plan accordingly and brings it in line before handing subtasks over to the Executor. The validation process could be repeated, by having the Verifier test the refined plan first.

In especially high stakes scenarios, the plan should be verified by the user (HITL) before the hand-off to the Executor. That should certainly be done for any use cases with potential harm to human dignity, rights or life which in addition may realistically require a second human approver. HITL can also avoid the Verifier and Refiner getting stuck in a verification and plan refinement loop and no agreement can be reached within a limited number of tries.

 

Quis Custodiet Ipsos Agentes? (Who Will Guard the Agents Themselves?)

With agents observing each other in this manner, utilizing various LLMs, statistical engines, or deterministic rule sets, and incorporating HITL, the likelihood of catastrophic emergent misalignment is significantly minimized. Backed by different methods, these agents are unlikely to fail or deceive in the same way. Even if the Planner implemented with a sophisticated reasoning model came up with a “paperclip maximizer” plan, the Verifier and HITL have an opportunity to catch it, before it is executed. Meanwhile, by providing the Executor with subtasks one-by-one, it can’t “look ahead” and abuse an agent or tool out of sequence.

This segregation of duties and intermediation of user requests across different agents makes agentic AI systems more resilient to misalignment. Auditable control points for Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC), managed execution flow, and least privileged access control on task level further strengthen that. The quartet of Planner, Executor, Verifier and Refiner keep each other in check, at critical junctions supplemented by HITL, including any potential four-eye review and approval. As the old IBM quote goes, “A computer can never be held accountable, therefore a computer must never make a management decision”. User-Involved Execution, where necessary extended with User-Involved Planning, centers human oversight and accountability.

 

Conclusion

Following the P-t-E pattern, agents are provided with limited trust, limited knowledge, and limited autonomy. Agents retain individual creativity while balancing each other out, rather than amplifying their potential for misaligned, deceptive and other undesirable behavior. Agentic AI systems designed along this pattern will behave more predictably and be easier to audit, without compromising their ability to complete complex workflows and objectives for their users.  

In the first part of the series, we discussed how difficult it is to control unsupervised agents. The second part offered a way to limit agent autonomy through least privilege access control. However, until part 3 we lacked an approach to enforce such controls through intermediation and agents-watching-agents. In this final part, we extended the P-t-E pattern with additional automated and human validation for higher risk use cases. Together, we hope they outline key new threats to consider in developing agentic AI systems, and how to guard against them.

 

More Information

  • When Thinking LLMs Lie: Unveiling the Strategic Deception in Representations of Reasoning Models (Arxiv, June 2025)
  • AI Lovers Grieve Loss of ChatGPT’s Old Model: ‘Like Saying Goodbye To Someone I Know’ (The Guardian, August 2025)
  • Nuclear Deployed: Analyzing Catastrophic Risks in Decision-making of Autonomous LLM Agents (ACL Anthology, July 2025)
  • Architecting Resilient LLM Agents: A Guide to Secure Plan-then-Execute Implementations, Ron F. Del Rosario, Klaudia Krawiecka, Christian Schroeder de Witt (ArXiv, Sep 2025)
  • “That’s Not What We Agreed!” – Repudiation and Agentic AI Threat Modeling (SAP Community)
  • Limiting Agent Autonomy – Least Privilege and Tool Access for Agentic AI Systems (SAP Community)
  • Plan-then-Execute – An Architectural Pattern for Responsible Agentic AI (SAP Community)

entry.title: Re: Getting high priority check after doing ATC
entry.content:
below is my code I also used the material number as it mentioned in BAPIMATDOA and its size is 40 but still getting the  Syntactically incompatible change of existing functionality (FUNC BAPI_MATERIAL_GET_DETAIL, see Note(s): 0002438131)
Finding can be suppressed with pseudo comment "#EC CI_USAGE_OK[2438131]   when i use bold code in front of BAPI function then check is gone but I don't want to use this each time in BAPI Function 

Is there any alternative

 

 

 FUNCTION zfm_get_material_details.
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------
*"*"Local Interface:
*" IMPORTING
*" VALUE(IM_MATERIAL) TYPE BAPIMATDOA-OLD_MAT_NO_LONG
*" EXPORTING
*" VALUE(EX_RETURN) TYPE BAPIRETURN
*" VALUE(EX_DETAILS) TYPE BAPIMATDOA
*"----------------------------------------------------------------------

DATA : lt_return TYPE bapireturn, "Structure to hold return messages from BAPI
lt_mara TYPE bapimatdoa. "Structure to hold general material data

"Call the BAPI to get material details
CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_MATERIAL_GET_DETAIL'
EXPORTING
MATERIAL_LONG = im_material
IMPORTING
MATERIAL_GENERAL_DATA = lt_mara
RETURN = lt_return.

"Assigning the BAPI return message to the exporting parameter
ex_return = lt_return.

"Assigning the fetched material details to the exporting parameter
ex_details = lt_mara.

ENDFUNCTION.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Accounts Receivable Functi...
entry.content:
Hi @byd 

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, the following
applies for your AR-related requirements:

1 Customer Acceptance Reconciliation - not standard
implement via SAP BTP or API-based custom process
2 AR/AP Offset for Same BP - standard when the
same BP has both AR & AP roles; manual clearing
otherwise.

3 Refund for Negative AR Balances - fully supported
in standard, with BCM integration and ISO20022
payment formats

4 Aging Receivables Management - standard Fiori
analytical apps (F0736, F1511, F2217) cover this
comprehensively.

Only requirement #1 would require a custom integration
or extension. All others are standard and available in
Public Cloud scope..

Best regards 

Chris

entry.title: KDM Transaction Key Not Triggering in Customizing System During MIRO Testing in S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Description:
Hello Experts,
In our SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (3-system landscape) – production system, we observed that during MIRO posting, the system creates a journal entry with the following lines:
• Vendor – Credit
• GR/IR – Debit
• BSX (Material) – Credit
• KDM – Credit
However, the G/L account assigned to KDM was maintained as a Balance Sheet account, which is incorrect.
We have corrected this in Automatic Account Determination by assigning a P&L G/L account for the KDM transaction key.
To validate this correction, we are trying to replicate the same MIRO posting in our customizing (test) tenant, but the system is not triggering the KDM line item.

• Test Scenario in Customizing System:
• Material with zero stock and price control = V (Moving Average)
• Supplier currency: EUR
• PO and GRN posted on 14th Oct with exchange rate (e.g. 1 EUR = X IQD)
• MIRO posted on 15th Oct with a different exchange rate
• Expected: KDM line to be triggered
• Actual: No KDM line item generated in accounting entry

• Our Objective:
We want to validate that the corrected P&L G/L account is being picked up for KDM before moving the configuration to production. Please suggest how can we trigger KDM key

entry.title: Re: Error 500 in CAP entitySet READ
entry.content:
@MioYasutake  Thank you for your reply.

My application.yaml was automatically generated with the same content as yours. So maybe it shouldn't be the issue here.

I later tried some other methods to fix the error mentioned above. Finally, I resolved it using the approach below (at least that error no longer appears, though I don't understand why). But thank you very much anyway.

I modified the structure/writing style of my .cds file.

Before:

service My_SRV {
    entity MoeSet as projection on TestSet;
}

entity TestSet {
    key testKey : String(64);
    inputData : String(100);
    memo: String(100);
    outputData: String(100);
}

 

After:

service My_SRV {
    entity TestSet {
		key testKey : String(64);
		inputData : String(100);
		memo: String(100);
		outputData: String(100);
    }
}

entry.title: Get information of actual parameters
entry.content:
Hi,

is it possible to retrieve information of actual parameters (arguments) in ABAP?

In my use case I want to know the identifier of the passed actual parameter of a method call.

Example:

...
METHODS do_anything
  IMPORTING
    parameter TYPE string.

...

METHOD do_anything
  DATA(name_of_actual_parameter) = get_name_actual_parameter( parameter ).
  " name_of_actual_parameter should contain as value my_variable
ENDMETHOD.

entry.title: SAP CS to S4HANA Service - End of Usage Right vs. Display Transactions in 2030+
entry.content:
SAP brought SAP CS as Compatibility Pack to S4HANA and informed in notes 2962632 and 2269324 that the product is discontinued with SAP S4HANA Service as successor as well as usage rights ends by 31/12/30.

Furthermore, there's a nice blog article describing what happens and how to move on.
A crucial topic ("Can documents and transactional data in Compatibility Scope still be displayed and can open business processes be finished?") is handled in chapter 8: can I access in read mode to my legacy data.

Though there's a general statement (I conclude reading access might still be possible since PM functionality will stay), it's referencing to the related Business Impact Note. As per "S4HANA CompScope - Way Forward - Info" Excel sheet, the respective note is again 2962632. There's no statement for the read-possibilities.

Is there any official statement confirming there is still read access to CS Service Orders/Notification beyond 2030 (without need to extract data to 3rd party solutions or pull the data in customer specific reports)?

 

Thank you very much!

entry.title: Re: Project-Based Services in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Hey there!

Great question—this is a classic SAP nuance that's tripped me up too. You're spot on: freight charges use the "Stock" checkbox to decide capitalization (adding to item cost via WIP) or expensing, but the expense clearing account is still needed for the journal entry balance during GRPO. It's not a direct expense post; it's an offset that reverses on inventory issue. For landed costs, it's more streamlined via the distribution rule in the landed cost document, without the checkbox—costs hit a clearing account first, then settle to inventory or COGS. The key difference is freight's line-level control vs. landed's document-level allocation.

For quick freight cost estimates in projects, I use kalkulatorpaliwa.com.pl to model scenarios before SAP entries—it helps spot variances early. Have you tried configuring OBYC for the clearing account yet, or is the DIP profile the bigger headache? Happy to brainstorm more!

entry.title: Install custom functions in COHV (1/3)
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP standard production orders information system, the COOIS transaction, is a very powerful and flexible tool to report various aspects of production and planned orders. It can be easily customized and enhanced.

The COHV transaction couples COOIS with order mass processing functions enhancing the PP information system even further. It provides various mass processing functions like order release, staging, costing, etc.

The note 1819470 - Mass processing functions are missing in t-code COHV has introduced two additional options to fix/delete fixing and to delete planned orders. The note shows that the mass processing capabilities of COHV can be enhanced. However, I have not been able to find any official extension points or documentation on how to add customer defined functions to COHV. This article is meant to close this gap and to present step-by-step instructions to implement new mass processing functions.

 

Enhance fixed values list of CO_FUNCT domain

The mass processing function list is defined with a reference to CO_FUNCT data element.

Figure 1: Technical details of the "Function" field in COHV

The data element refers to the CO_FUNCT domain.

Figure 2: The CO_FUNCT data element details

The list of mass processing functions available in COHV is defined with fixed values of the CO_FUNCT domain. Notice that the list has already been enhanced with 205 and 215 functions delivered with the note 1819470 - Mass processing functions are missing in t-code COHV

Figure 3: The fixed values of the CO_FUNCT domain

Therefore, the first step is to add a custom function code to the fixed values of the domain. The exact procedure is described on SAP Help: Creating Fixed Value Appends 

Figure 4: The fixed values of the CO_FUNCT domain enhanced with a custom function

 

Register the custom function

The next step is to register the custom function with COHV. That is done in the include LCOWORKF06, the FORM routine REGISTERED_FUNCTIONS_INIT

SAP provides the enhancement spot ES_SAPLCOWORK to register additional functions. However, it is for SAP internal use only. Unfortunately, there are no standard enhancements available here either. Therefore, I am going to use implicit enhancement at the end of the routine.

The fct_icon field is optional, but it is a nice touch to have an icon assigned to the mass processing function.

 

Add the custom function in the COISL transaction

Finally, the custom function needs to be assigned to order information list type in the COISL transaction.

 

Final result

The final result is that the custom function is visible and selectable in COHV.

Figure 5: The custom function in the COHV initial screen

 It is also available as a push button with the icon assigned in the registration step in the COHV toolbar.

Figure 6: The custom function in the COHV toolbar

The custom function is also visible and executable from the COHV results list. 

Naturally, the custom function does not do anything for now. The function execution implementation is the topic of the next episode. Stay tuned…
